activities.message: We've gone through this a couple times in the past. We're basically dependent on AWS's default security policies, since that's what Heroku uses.

We don't have direct access to AWS, because we use Heroku.

Hello,

Again this is still possible as per heroku documentation :https://devcenter.heroku.com/articles/ssl-endpoint
 
Thanks
@mmyamin Actually, sorry. You were reporting for `grtp.co`, which is on Digital Ocean, not Heroku (that's `gratipay.com`).

SSL labs does show some problems with our configuration of `grtp.co`:

https://www.ssllabs.com/ssltest/analyze.html?d=grtp.co

Hi @mmyamin, 

I used the following tools to estimate the quality of Heroku's SSL/TLS:
- SSLLabs: Heroku gets a A. See the [report](https://www.ssllabs.com/ssltest/analyze.html?d=gratipay.com&s=54.243.36.213&latest). No well-known attack seems to be usable against their infrastructure, and the "cipher strength" score is not bad. But nothing about Logjam.
- KeyCDN: Heroku is no more impacted by Logjam, according to [this tool](https://tools.keycdn.com/logjam).

You recommend us to remove the ciphers based on 3DES ([which are still present in the Intermediate compatibility cipher list suggested by mozilla](https://wiki.mozilla.org/Security/Server_Side_TLS)) but the link you gave us says nothing about it. Can you provide us more details about why you think this is an real issue?

The only way to make our SSL ~~great again~~ better would be to follow [the same process that whit537 did](https://github.com/gratipay/security-2a443f/issues/1) ([even if it seems to be automatic now](https://devcenter.heroku.com/changelog-items/816)), but I don't think it's worth. 

Furthermore, concerning SSH, I have strong reasons to believe these ciphers could not be considered as "weak". Your report references an old CVE for one OpenSSH version which is not currently in use. I found [a publication](http://www.isg.rhul.ac.uk/~kp/SandPfinal.pdf) which seems related with what you said. However, I can't find any strong argument proving that the current implementation of CBC ciphers inside our version in use of OpenSSH is *really* unsafe. 

I'm suggesting to close this report as "Informative".

TL;DR: For SSL and SSH ciphers, I don't think we have control over it and it's not worth to try.

> the quality of Heroku's SSL/TLS

I made this same mistake ... we're talking about `grtp.co` here (Digital Ocean), not `gratipay.com` (Heroku). :o)
Accepting as a theoretical risk, which carries a $1 bounty per [our program description](https://hackerone.com/gratipay).

God, that's right, sorry! You even posted it while I was typing my message ;-(
I still think we can't consider the reported ciphers as weak, for the same reasons. 

Concerning the ssllabs score for https://grtp.co, it seems to be only related to the *small* DH value, not related to what @mmyamin reported (maybe with what's highlighted in the first screen, but talking with a screenshot is not very easy) and not vulnerable to the logjam attack.

To continue about this story of DH, in another report (#117458, not public atm), @hammad said:
> As far as I am aware, breaking 1024-bit is well out of the range of a standard attacker (non nation-state). Also grtp.co is a static site, there's nothing interesting for the attacker. If you can comeup with something like this on Gratipay.com that would be worth fixing.

I don't think it's only a problem of interception, but of alteration of the content too. If somebody (organization/state/…) can alter our files while they are being sent to the client, it's an issue for everybody. It's not very hard to increase the DH group to 2048, that's why I'm finally OK with the fact it's a "Theoretical risk" (if take a look at the first screenshot and not the report) and I believe we should reward #117458 the same.

> I'm finally OK with the fact it's a "Theoretical risk"

I think we should aim to maintain an A grade on SSLLabs for both `grtp.co` and `gratipay.com`, and consider it a theoretical risk if we drop below that. You okay with that?

> I believe we should reward #117458 the same.

Sounds good to me. May I let you do the honors? :)

> I think we should aim to maintain an A grade on SSLLabs for both grtp.co and gratipay.com, and consider it a theoretical risk if we drop below that. You okay with that?

Nice, very easy to remind! I think it could even be added to the "Out of Scope" part of our policy (it seems you're the only one to be able to do it).

> Sounds good to me. May I let you do the honors? :)

Done ;-) Now opening an issue on [gratipay/grtp.co](https://github.com/gratipay/grtp.co) describing the commands to run on the server to fix this.

activities.message:
I've expanded the scope of this ticket to be about getting up to an A grade on SSLLabs.

Weak DH [fixed](https://github.com/gratipay/grtp.co/pull/145). Now SSLLabs shows:

> This server's certificate chain is incomplete. Grade capped to B.

https://www.ssllabs.com/ssltest/analyze.html?d=grtp.co
It's being tracked [on Github](https://github.com/gratipay/grtp.co/issues/146).

thanks for the acknowledgment,

just for @nashe_ 

1)SSH brute force attack is one of the most popular attack over the internet i still suggest to close the port when SSH service is not needed also hmac-md 5 and CBC ciphers are not compliant to PCI DSS standards take a look in those standards there is reason why the are not consider safe 
2)Weak SSL Ciphers assist in MIMA and  slowloris

Regarding SSH:
* Bruteforce : we need SSH. This should not impacting us if we have the right password policy. Don't hesitate to open a report if you think we're using a weak password on our server. Allowing only SSH public keys may be an improvement but it's not related to this report—accepting it's best practice.
* PCI DSS : Gratipay is not compliant with PCI DSS, but may [want to](https://github.com/gratipay/inside.gratipay.com/issues/214). However, I can't find enough data about what you're claiming, most especially for ciphers related to SSH. Can you tell me more?

Regarding the SSL ciphers:
 * As far I know, while doing a MITM attack, you need to force the client to establish a new tunnel between him and you, then you'll create a new one with the remote server. Being able to modify the content "on the wire" (without making the target establish a new tunnel) seems to be more related to implementation problems (malleability and no authentication of the data, [weird implementations](https://github.com/nonce-disrespect/nonce-disrespect) or [versions of the protocol which we are not using](http://crypto.stackexchange.com/a/1082)). I don't think it's related to us.
 * Slowloris is about maintaining open a lot of active connexions at once, I don't see how this is related to SSL/TLS. Furthermore, we are running nginx, which seems to be less disposed to behave the same way than Apache (aka. not handling any new connexion) when being attacked with this method. In addition, we are not receiving reports about "Network-level DoS".

kindly review this document PCI DSS Crytographic requirement:
https://cryptosense.com/pci-dss-crypto-compliance/
For SSH over the internet the answer here :http://serverfault.com/questions/521829/are-using-ssh-keys-pci-compliant explains why it is not compliant

For MITM due to weak cipher support attack please review the website: https://weakdh.org/

about slowloris you are are it was my mistake thanks

Here are my thoughts about theses documents:
* The first one is not telling we should not use CBC ciphers (you did not even mentioned `arcfour`…). Related extract of the PCI DSS document: `Note that some protocol implementations (such as SSL, SSH v1.0, and early TLS) for example, (...) by using only trusted certificates and supporting only strong encryption (not supporting weaker, insecure protocols or methods)`. It's very vague. I think that using ONLY elliptic curves everywhere (when they are not backdoored!) and authenticated AES256 "just because" is more related to paranoia/fashion than a direct security risk. Unless you can prove there is one, I'm longer willing to discuss of this subject in this report—it's not the right place. Open a ticket on [gratipay/grtp.co](https://github.com/gratipay/grtp.co/issues) if you want to continue to discuss. 

* Same response for 2FA. 

By the way, `grtp.co` is only serving static content and does not have any privileged access/permissions/shared volume/… with the infrastructure responsible of the payments. I don't think PCI DSS needs to apply here.

* Concerning Logjam/small DH group/common DH, we were not vulnerable but [we still increased its size to 2048 today](https://github.com/gratipay/grtp.co/issues/144). It's not related to "weak ciphers" in any way.

just to confirm your setting i suggest you to run a nexpose scan (full audit) https://www.rapid7.com/products/nexpose/ it's free and  it will clearly identify what the issues are in ciphers i can do it but as per Bug Hunting Policy automatic scanning tools are not allowed
Thanks

If you want, you can open an issue on [our repository](https://github.com/gratipay/grtp.co/) to tell us your results after running a scan and discuss the results. Note that it won't be part of the bug bounty program.

> i can do it but as per Bug Hunting Policy automatic scanning tools are not allowed

I guess that running `nmap` with `--script` can be described as "automated scanning" too ;-)

We have [fixed](https://github.com/gratipay/grtp.co/issues/146) everything we wanted to and [ssllabs is now giving a A](https://www.ssllabs.com/ssltest/analyze.html?d=grtp.co) without telling that some ciphers are too weak or vulnerable to some known attack, which was our goal.

Thanks for making Gratipay a safer place!
